results.title: Checking up (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Parents and teachers may find themselves questioning the value of new methods of learning which are being used in many British schools, and are being encouraged by the Schools Council and the Nuffield Foundation Mathematics Teaching Project. Examines the question of keeping individual records of day to day progress as opposed to conventional attainment tests.

results.title: Childhood aggression: a social learning approach to family therapy (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Steven D McAdam, Phillip R. Blake, Oregan Research Institute and PRB Productions
results.brief_description: This film documents Tim’s aggressive behaviour, how it makes the family miserable and hinders Tim at school. Once the need for help has been established, the family contact the Oregan Research Institute Family Centre and move through the treatment process. The widespread changes occurring within the family as treatment progresses is shown.

results.title: A Child went forth
results.creator_credit: John Ferno, Joseph Losey and New York University Film Library
results.brief_description: A study of an experimental nursery school for children between the ages of 2 and 7 years. The nursery school was founded during the war, when many parents were working and therefore unable to give their children the care the needed. It proved such a success that the school was continued after the war. The children were encouraged in those activities which helped to develop their self-reliance and independence. In close contact with nature, under conditions, as primitive as was consistent with safety, they learned how to live together, to develop self-discipline, to use their creative instincts in ways which yielded them satisfaction. The film relates the activities of this nursery school with more general techniques of progressive educational theory, and emphasises the potential value of such nursery-schools. Commentary written by Munro Leaf; narrated by Lloyd Gough.

results.title: The Child watchers
results.creator_credit: Jean Oser, L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
The reflexes of a newborn baby are the basis for early learning, this is shown to be more extensive than was once thought. Experiments by developmental psychologists such as Piaget and Brunner are demonstrated with children up to the age of 6. Based on the book “The Mind” by John Rowan Wilson - a volume in the Life Science Library. Narrated by Luis Van Rooten. Suggested audience: senior secondary, tertiary, general.

results.title: Child of the future: how he might learn
results.creator_credit: Theodore Conant and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Education is increasingly affected by technological advances. Shows how schools and colleges are shedding their traditional apathy to machines and are now exploiting all manner of mechanical and electronic aids and how these changes affect the child. Several leading educators and innovators including Dr. Marshall McLuhan and Dr. Jerome Bruner of Havard University discuss the ways traditional practice is adapting to radical new methods.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Theodore Conant and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Child in the middle
results.creator_credit: Gerard Schaefer, Merrill S. Brody and University of California, Los Angeles. Dept. of Theater Arts
results.brief_description: Underlines the importance of co-operation by parents and teachers in reaching understanding of children’s problems. In a dramatised example (based on an actual case), Martha causes concern to her teacher when she withdraws from school work and school contacts. The teacher discovers that Martha is throwing away the lunch cut by her grandmother, who also figures oddly in Martha’s free expression art work. Discussion with the parents and the headmistress clears the way for Martha’s readjustment to school life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gerard Schaefer, Merrill S. Brody and University of California, Los Angeles. Dept. of Theater Arts

results.title: Child guidance clinic [Abridged version]
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, Allen Stark and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Narrator Neil Leroy drops in at the Child Adjustment Services center for the study and treatment of the emotionally disturbed child set up by the Toronto Board of Education. Here, psychologists, social workers and psychiatrists, with the cooperation of parents and teachers, are learning how to deal with children’s emotional problems and to help them develop into healthy, happy adults. Through the story of young Nick, we see how early diagnosis and treatment of a child’s maladjustment can change him into a normal, outgoing youngster.

results.title: Child behaviour = you
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Would you pick up a baby when he cries for attention, or let him yell out his little lungs? This cartoon film for parents poses many such questions that confront a mother during the course of her day. Made with the counsel of child specialists, it provides a perceptive guide to understanding what motivates both good and problem behavior in children from infancy to adolescence, and how to draw out the best.

results.title: Chik's great adventure
results.brief_description: The story of Scouting in Malaya. Chik’s “great adventure” began when he joined the Boy Scouts because scouting gave him adventure, companionship, healthy activity and an opportunity for service in his community. The film provides useful information on the aims and objects of the Scout Movement in Malaya.
